name: Decode

aliases.name: Decoder
aliases.comment: A value that knows how to decode EDN elements.

values.name: andThen
values.comment: Create a decoder that depends on the result of a previous decoder.
values.type: (a -> Decode.Decoder b) -> Decode.Decoder a -> Decode.Decoder b

values.name: at
values.comment:
Decode a nested object, requiring certain fields.

    decodeString (at ["end", "x"] float)
        """{:start {:x 1.0, :y 1.5}
            :end   {:x 0.5, :y 0.334}}"""
    --> Ok 0.5

    decodeString (at ["start", "z"] float)
        """{:start {:x 1.0, :y 1.5}
            :end   {:x 0.5, :y 0.334}}"""
    --> Err "field not found: z"
values.type: List String -> Decode.Decoder a -> Decode.Decoder a

values.name: bool
values.comment:
Decode an EDN boolean into an Elm `Bool`.

     decodeString bool "true"   --> Ok True
     decodeString bool "false"  --> Ok False
     decodeString bool "nil"    --> Err "expected a boolean but found `nil`"
     decodeString bool "(true)" --> Err "expected a boolean but found a list"

values.name: char
values.comment:
Decode an EDN character into an Elm `Char`.

    decodeString char "\\a"       --> Ok 'a'
    decodeString char "\\newline" --> Ok '\n'
    decodeString char "\\\\"      --> Ok '\\'
    decodeString char "\\u0026"   --> Ok '&'

values.name: decodeString
values.comment:
Parse the given string into a single EDN element and
and decode it to an Elm value using the given Decoder.
values.type: Decode.Decoder a -> String -> Result.Result String a

values.name: dict
values.comment:
Decode an EDN map into an Elm `Dict`.

    import Dict

    decodeString
        (dict int string)
        """{12 "onetwo", 21 "twoone", 3 "three"}"""
    --> Ok <| Dict.fromList
    -->     [ (12, "onetwo")
    -->     , (21, "twoone")
    -->     , (3,  "three")
    -->     ]
values.type: Decode.Decoder comparable -> Decode.Decoder value -> Decode.Decoder (Dict.Dict comparable value)

values.name: fail
values.comment: Ignore the input and make the decoder fail with the given message.

values.name: field
values.comment:
Decode an EDN map field.

    decodeString (field "twitter" string)
        """{:name "Alice", :twitter "@alice"}"""
    --> Ok "@alice"

    decodeString (field "twitter" string)
        """{:name "Bob", :icq 12345678}"""
    --> Err "field not found: twitter"

    decodeString (field "twitter" (optional string))
        """{:name "Alice", :twitter "@alice"}"""
    --> Ok (Just "@alice")

    decodeString (field "twitter" (optional string))
        """{:name "Eve", :twitter nil}"""
    --> Ok Nothing

values.name: float
values.comment:
Decode an EDN floating point number into an Elm `Float`

     decodeString float "1.1" --> Ok 1.1
     decodeString float "1E1" --> Ok 10.0
     decodeString float "2"
     --> Err "expected a floating point number but found an integer"

values.name: index
values.comment:
Decode an EDN vector, requiring a particular index.

    decodeString (index 1 int)
        """["one" 2 3.0 nil]"""
    --> Ok 2
    decodeString (index 1 int)
        "[1]"
    --> Err "index 1 not found in vector of length 1"

This will fail on EDN lists.

    decodeString (index 1 int)
        "(1 2 3)"
    --> Err "expected a vector but found a list"

values.name: instant
values.comment:
Decode an EDN instant to an Elm `Date`. An EDN instant
is a tagged string of an ISO 8601 date.

    import Date

    decodeString instant
        "#inst \"1985-04-12T23:20:50.52Z\""
    --> Date.fromString "1985-04-12T23:20:50.52Z"
    decodeString instant
        "#inst \"1985-04-12T23:20:50.52+04:00\""
    --> Date.fromString "1985-04-12T23:20:50.52+04:00"
    decodeString instant
        "\"1985-04-12T23:20:50.52Z\""
    --> Err "expected a tagged element but found a string"

values.name: int
values.comment:
Decode an EDN integer into an Elm `Int`.

    decodeString int "12345" --> Ok 12345
    decodeString int "1.0"   --> Err "expected an integer but found a floating point number"

values.name: keyValuePairs
values.comment:
Decode an EDN map into an Elm `List` of pairs. If the keys are
simple (strings, integers, keywords, ...), consider using
[`dict`](#dict) or [`field`](#field) instead.

    decodeString
        (keyValuePairs (list int) string)
        """{(1 2) "onetwo"
            (2 1) "twoone"
            ()    "three"}"""
    --> Ok [ ([1, 2], "onetwo")
    -->    , ([2, 1], "twoone")
    -->    , ([], "three")
    -->    ]
values.type: Decode.Decoder key -> Decode.Decoder value -> Decode.Decoder (List ( key, value ))

values.name: keyword
values.comment:
Decode an EDN keyword into an Elm `String`.

     decodeString keyword ":black" --> Ok "black"
     decodeString keyword "yo"     --> Err "expected a keyword but found a symbol"
     decodeString keyword ":true"  --> Ok "true"

values.name: list
values.comment:
Decode an EDN list into an Elm `List`.

    decodeString
        (list int)
        "(1 2 3 4 5)"
    --> Ok [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

    decodeString
        (list (list string))
        """(() ("hello" "world") ())"""
    --> Ok [[], ["hello", "world"], []]

values.name: map
values.comment: Transform a decoder.

values.name: map2
values.comment:
Try two decoders and then combine the result. We can use this to decode
objects with many fields:

    type alias Point =
        { x : Float, y : Float }

    point : Decoder Point
    point =
        map2 Point
            (field "x" float)
            (field "y" float)

    decodeString point """{:x 3.0, :y 4.0}"""
    --> Ok { x = 3, y = 4 }

It tries each individual decoder and puts the result together with the `Point`
constructor.
values.type: (a -> b -> value) -> Decode.Decoder a -> Decode.Decoder b -> Decode.Decoder value

values.name: map3
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> value) -> Decode.Decoder a -> Decode.Decoder b -> Decode.Decoder c -> Decode.Decoder value

values.name: map4
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> value) -> Decode.Decoder a -> Decode.Decoder b -> Decode.Decoder c -> Decode.Decoder d -> Decode.Decoder value

values.name: map5
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> value) -> Decode.Decoder a -> Decode.Decoder b -> Decode.Decoder c -> Decode.Decoder d -> Decode.Decoder e -> Decode.Decoder value

values.name: map6
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> value) -> Decode.Decoder a -> Decode.Decoder b -> Decode.Decoder c -> Decode.Decoder d -> Decode.Decoder e -> Decode.Decoder f -> Decode.Decoder value

values.name: map7
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> g -> value) -> Decode.Decoder a -> Decode.Decoder b -> Decode.Decoder c -> Decode.Decoder d -> Decode.Decoder e -> Decode.Decoder f -> Decode.Decoder g -> Decode.Decoder value

values.name: map8
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> g -> h -> value) -> Decode.Decoder a -> Decode.Decoder b -> Decode.Decoder c -> Decode.Decoder d -> Decode.Decoder e -> Decode.Decoder f -> Decode.Decoder g -> Decode.Decoder h -> Decode.Decoder value

values.name: nil
values.comment:
Decode an EDN nil value.

     decodeString keyword ":nil" --> Ok "nil"
     decodeString keyword "yo"   --> Err "expected a keyword but found a symbol"
     decodeString keyword "nil"  --> Err "expected a keyword but found `nil`"

values.name: oneOf
values.comment:
Try a bunch of different decoders, one after the other. The
result is the value of the first successful decoder.

    type ID
        = UserID Int
        | Email String

    decodeString
        (list <| oneOf
            [ map UserID int
            , map Email string
            ])
        """(1, "alice@example.com", 334)"""
    --> Ok
    -->     [ UserID 1
    -->     , Email "alice@example.com"
    -->     , UserID 334
    -->     ]

values.name: optional
values.comment:
Decode an EDN nil value into `Nothing`, or any other value into an Elm value.

     decodeString (optional bool) "true" --> Ok (Just True)
     decodeString (optional bool) "nil"  --> Ok Nothing

values.name: optionalField
values.comment:
Decode an optional EDN map field.

    decodeString (optionalField "twitter" string)
        """{:name "Alice", :twitter "@alice"}"""
    --> Ok (Just "@alice")

    decodeString (optionalField "twitter" string)
        """{:name "Bob", :icq 12345678}"""
    --> Ok Nothing

    decodeString (optionalField "twitter" string)
        """{:name "Eve", :twitter nil}"""
    --> Err "expected a string but found `nil`"

values.name: set
values.comment:
Decode an EDN set into an Elm `Set`.

    import Set

    decodeString (set int) "#{1, 2}"
    --> Ok (Set.fromList [1, 2])

values.name: string
values.comment:
Decode an EDN string into an Elm `String`.

    decodeString string "\"12345\"" --> Ok "12345"
    decodeString string "\"ðŸ˜ž\""    --> Ok "ðŸ˜ž"
    decodeString string "12345"     --> Err "expected a string but found an integer"

values.name: succeed
values.comment: Ignore the input and make the decoder succeed with the given value.

values.name: symbol
values.comment:
Decode an EDN symbol into an Elm `String`.

     decodeString symbol "yo"     --> Ok "yo"
     decodeString symbol ":black" --> Err "expected a symbol but found a keyword"

values.name: tag
values.comment:
Decode a tagged element.

    decodeString (tag "my/tag" int) "#my/tag 55"
    --> Ok 55
    decodeString (tag "my/tag" int) "#your/tag 55"
    --> Err "expected tag `my/tag` but found `your/tag`"
    decodeString (tag "my/tag" int) "55"
    --> Err "expected a tagged element but found an integer"

values.name: tagged
values.comment:
Decode an element based on its tag.

    type ID
        = UserID Int
        | Email String

    decodeString
        (list <| tagged
            [ ( "my/uid",   map UserID int   )
            , ( "my/email", map Email string )
            ])
        """(#my/uid 1, #my/email "alice@example.com", #my/uid 334)"""
    --> Ok <|
    -->     [ UserID 1
    -->     , Email "alice@example.com"
    -->     , UserID 334
    -->     ]
values.type: List ( String, Decode.Decoder a ) -> Decode.Decoder a

values.name: vector
values.comment:
Decode an EDN vector into an Elm `List`.

    decodeString (vector int) "[2 2]"
    --> Ok [2, 2]

name: Encode

aliases.name: Element
aliases.comment:
An EDN element.

This can be encoded to a `String` via [`encode`](encode).

types.name: Keyword
types.comment:
An EDN keyword. You can make these from strings using
`toKeyword` or `mustKeyword`.

types.name: Symbol
types.comment:
An EDN symbol. You can make these from strings using
`toSymbol` or `mustSymbol`.

types.name: Tag
types.comment:
An EDN tag. You can make these from strings using
`toTag` or `mustTag`.

values.name: encode
values.comment:
Encode an EDN element to EDN.

    encode (list [int 5, string "hello"])
    --> """(5 "hello")"""

values.name: float
values.comment: Make an EDN floating point number from an Elm `Float`.

values.name: int
values.comment: Make an EDN integer from an Elm `Int`.

values.name: keyword
values.comment:
Make an EDN keyword from a `Keyword`.

    encode <| keyword  <| mustKeyword "nil"
    --> ":nil"

values.name: list
values.comment: Make an EDN list from an Elm `List` of EDN elements.

values.name: mustKeyword
values.comment:
Create a `Keyword` from an Elm `String`, crashing if
it is not a valid symbol.

values.name: mustObject
values.comment:
Make an EDN object (map from keyword to element) from a list of
pairs of field name string and field value. This will crash if any of
the field names are not valid EDN symbols.

    encode (mustObject [ ("x", float 1.5), ("y", float 0.0) ])
    --> "{:x 1.5, :y 0.0}"

values.name: mustSymbol
values.comment:
Create a `Symbol` from an Elm `String`, crashing if
it is not a valid symbol.

values.name: mustTag
values.comment:
Create a `Tag` from an Elm `String`, crashing if
it is not a valid symbol.

values.name: mustTagged
values.comment:
Make a tagged EDN element from a `String` and an element.
This will crash if the tag is not a valid EDN symbol.

    type ID
        = UserID Int
        | Email String

    encode <| list <|
        List.map (\id -> case id of
            UserID i -> mustTagged "my/uid" (int i)
            Email e  -> mustTagged "my/email" (string e)
        ) [ UserID 5, Email "alice@example.com" ]
    --> """(#my/uid 5 #my/email "alice@example.com")"""

values.name: object
values.comment:
Make an EDN object (map from keyword to element) from a list of
pairs of field name symbol and field value.

    case (toKeyword "x", toKeyword "y") of
        (Just x, Just y)
            -> encode (object [ (x, float 1.5), (y, float 0.0) ])
        _   -> ""
    --> "{:x 1.5, :y 0.0}"

values.name: string
values.comment: Make an EDN string from an Elm `String`.

values.name: symbol
values.comment: Make an EDN symbol from a `Symbol`.

values.name: tagged
values.comment: Make a tagged EDN element from a tag and an element.

values.name: toKeyword
values.comment:
Create a `Keyword` from an Elm `String`. This allows the
same strings as `toSymbol`, in addition to `"nil"`, `"true"`
and `"false"`.

values.name: toSymbol
values.comment:
Create a `Symbol` from an Elm `String`. This will fail
and return `Nothing` if the string is not a valid symbol, compare
the [EDN spec](https://github.com/edn-format/edn#symbols).

`nil`, `true` and `false` are not valid symbols.

values.name: toTag
values.comment:
Create a `Tag` from an Elm `String`. This allows the
same strings as `toSymbol`, in addition to `"nil"`, `"true"`
and `"false"`.
